description: Study of diverse genres and disciplines of acting; fundamental techniques necessary for performance; scene study from contemporary text.
Introduction to the theoretical and foundational practices, techniques and strategies specific to screen acting in relation to the basic dynamics of acting for the stage.
Basic training for the actor's body for expression and communication. Awareness and control through mind-body techniques.
Basic principles and techniques of acting through theatre games and improvisation. Introduction to contemporary texts, basic characterization and cold reading techniques.
Individual and group exercises to free the actor physically and emotionally and to stimulate creativity, imagination, and self-expression.
Focuses on the questions, artistic choices, methodologies, and approaches of an actor/director/designer in the preparation of a production score prior to rehearsal.
Introduction to the non-performance areas of theatrical production(administrative, design, and technical fields) through hands-onparticipation in USC productions.

sections.instructor: Elizabeth Harper,Tak Kata,Ann Closs-Farley,Noel Nichols,Tony Shayne

description: Advanced understanding of non-performance areas of theatrical production (administrative, design, and technical fields) through hands-on participation in USC productions.
A guided student exploration of the fundamentals of applied design elements and their use as creative tools in the design process
A comprehensive overview and understanding of how stand-up evolved in the United States, from the mid-1800's to the current touring performers.
Comedy and Performance traces the history of comedy in performance from its earliest incarnations to the present day.

course_name: The Actor's Instrument: Voice and Body
description: A comprehensive exploration of voice, speech and acting to strengthen the actors physical instrument.
Training and practice in the coordination of the physical apparatus of the actor utilizing various movement techniques through improvisation.
Continuing development of imagination leading to an increased range of dramatic expression through the formalized text of William Shakespeare.
Principles of stage make-up materials and skills allowing the actors to enhance their features and techniques for moderate and extreme aging, injuries, and character roles.
The visualization and communication of design ideas through free-hand and mechanical drawing: orthographics, isometrics,perspective, shades and shadows, plans, sections and elevations.
Historical survey, theory and practice in construction of costume.
Theory and practice of theatrical lighting design including electricity, radiant energy, refraction, reflection, absorption, chromatic variation and electronic controls.
Historical survey, theory and practice of the use of costume in theatrical production; emphasis on period and style.
Basic audio engineering science, how sound is measured, basic transducers and signal flow. Operation of recording and playback equipment used in theatrical sound design/mixing.
Understanding on-camera acting and improvisation by creating original material both in front and behind the camera.
Polishing the actor's skills through analysis and performance applied to the arc of a character.
Polishing the actor's skills through analysis and performance applied to the arc of a character.
Explores the art of clowning in hospitals for the purpose of improving the well-being of those in need.
Current state of American theatre, through a study of acting, playwriting, criticism, stage design, lighting, and dramatic styles.
Examination of basic directorial principles. Pre-production analysis and rehearsal procedures; relationship of the director to actor; integration of technical aspects of production.
Experiential and discussion-based; examines Los Angeles-based live comedy as it continues to evolve, both through text and performance.
Explores the range and genealogy of LGBTQ theatre and performance across political, historical, and theatrical contexts.
20th century realism and the avant-garde.
Actor training anchored by rigorous physical movements. Activities include comdey, clowning, juggling, and mask work. Open to BFA acting majors only.
Develops the ability to create a podcast. Focuses on skills to produce, perform, market and monetize a podcast across a variety of genres.
Further development of range and breadth of performance skills with emphasis on texts of heightened language and style.
An in depth study of improvised comedy scene work. An exploration of the primary tools and structure for creating improvised scenes and developing characters for stage and screen.
Historical styles, methods, and dramatic analysis for scene design as applied in contemporary practice.
Historical styles, methods, and dramatic analysis in costume design as applied in contemporary practice. Execution of costume designs for assigned works.
Historical styles, methods and dramatic analysis in lighting design as applied in contemporary practice.
Basic skills, including assembly of prompt book, blocking notation, and organizational and communication procedures applied in theater production.
Technology, organization, and operation of the theatrical scene shop centered around the proper and safe use of tools, the choosing of materials, and methods of construction.

course_name: The Actor's Instrument: Voice and Body II
description: Continued training in the areas of breath awareness, physical awareness, voice, speech work and movement training.
Extended development of vocal freedom and range, acquisition of articulate speech. Enhancement of vocal power and resonance, techniques for performing with a dialect. Open to BFA acting majors only.
a: Examination of the individual voice centering on resonance, tone, flexibility, and support through dramatic selections for transmitting meaning and emotion of character.
Examination of the individual voice centering on resonance, tone, flexibility, and support through dramatic selections for transmitting meaning and emotion of character. Continuation of 342a.
Designed to give students confidence and integrity for auditions in musical theatre. Choosing appropriate material and preparation for the audition and performance. Audition required.
Building and sustaining character with special focus on stylized realism, subtext and heightened language. Multi-cultural text and methodologies.
Building and sustaining character with special focus on stylized realism, subtext and heightened language. Multi-cultural text and methodologies.
Basic approach to the acting and analysis of the highly formalized texts of William Shakespeare.
Provide an understanding as to how to work in half-hour television and streaming media.
Essential elements of playwriting through weekly assignments, students' initiative, occasional productions of scenes, and extensive classroom analysis.
Continuation of the work begun in 365.
A focus on American ethnic and multicultural diversity from the perspectives of gender, race, and myth as revealed in plays, film, and other performance media.
Substantive participation in a production sponsored by the School and supervised by the faculty.
Projection design process, software, equipment, multi-media and digital technology concepts, and related documentation.
Examination of the theoretical foundations of acting as an art form through the reading of primary historical texts.
This course explores the live performance medium as a creative means of social redress and personal expression. Duplicates credit in the former THTR 393m.
An exploration of the art of theatre at the edge of possibilities.

course_name: Drawing and Rendering for the Theater
description: Drawing and rendering techniques appropriate for theater designers. Drawing and rendering.
The study of standard American stage dialect using the international phonetic alphabet.
An exploration of computer aided drafting (CAD) software, including drafting standards as achieved with Vectorworks and related software.
Empowers the student to forge a career in acting by managing and utilizing the many facets of social and digital media.
Develops the student's ability to connect and combine managerial, economic and business-related skills with the craft and career of acting.
Development of skills to create content for stage and screen.
Contemporary material from plays and screenplays with an emphasis on individual challenges and problems.

course_name: Public Speaking as Performance: A Course for Non-Actors
description: Public speaking approached as performance, using acting techniques to communicate with confidence, clarity and charisma.
The dramatic art of making an audience believe something is impossible. the history and performance of magic including illusion, mentalism, vanishing, coin and card tricks.
Explores the tools required to forge a career as a contemporary creator, with an emphasis on producing and monetizing new work through modern platforms.

course_name: Being on Screen: A Class for Presenters, Hosts, and Others
description: Exploration of on-camera skills required for presenters, hosts, athletes, public speakers, and others whose careers will include on-screen appearances.

course_name: Audition Technique for Film, Television and New Media
description: Develop on-camera auditioning skills for actors at a professional level in a variety of film, television and new media venues.
Continuation of 330. Evolution of scene design through analysis of script, environmental factors, and styles.
Evolution of costume design through analysis of script, environmental factors, and styles.
Continuation of THTR 332. Evolution of lighting design through analysis of script, environmental factors and styles.
Introduction to electronic sound and sound reinforcement, including basic equipment, recording, editing, and show operation.
Theory and practice of technical theatre. Emphasis is on technical problem solving and graphic solutions to technical theatre.
Organization, management, and construction of properties for the theatre.
Acting techniques, recording studio technology and editing for the field of voice acting and voice-overs.

The context and scope of work done by a Theatrical Production Manager. Students will learn about different types of theatrical organizations and how they are structured. Prerequisite: THTR 333. Recommended preparation: two units of THTR 397.
Development of resonance, range and clarity. Examination of posture and breathwork. Applications of voice skills to acting, professional speaking and personal projects.
Adapt the fundamentals tools of scene and character analysis to the specialized world of voice acting for English dubbing.
Analysis of key influencers and aesthetics within relevant digital platforms for the fashion industry.

course_name: History of Fashion and the Costume
description: Introduction to four hundred years of fashion history drawing parallels between the fashion and period that it existed.
Focus on advanced acting, theatrical interdisciplinary storytelling styles explored in epic theatre.
Explores the range and genealogy of Latinx theatre and performance from its origins in the last fifty years to the present.
Using original and existing scripted material for film, television and new media students will act, film and edit scenes to form a professional performance reel.
Analysis of a full-length play or its equivalent with continued production opportunity.

course_name: Going Viral: Performance for New Media
description: A writing and performance course (partially online) for new media. Students will learn to create original short form and web series content for new media including YouTube, Funny or Die, Periscope and other Internet platforms.
A writing-performance workshop in which the students create, rehearse and perform original sketch comedy material.
Introduction to the skills, knowledge, and promotional materials that will enable the student to manage an independent career in the performing arts.
An introduction to the discipline of conceiving, writing, and creating original Stand Up Comedy routines

course_name: Acting on Camera: The Collaborative Process
description: Acting students will learn to develop on-camera acting skills and to collaborate with student directors and cinematographers from the School of Cinematic Arts.
A writing-performance workshop in which students write, develop, and rehearse original, autobiographical and character monologues and perform them at the end of the semester.
Structured to address the dynamics of acting in relation to film/television. Refining the students' understanding of the similarities/differences between acting on stage/film.
Continued exploration of acting for film/television. Furthering the student's understanding of the similarities/differences between acting on stage/film.
Interactive performance and writing intensive focusing on creating professional level comedy material plus onstage performance strategies.
An on-camera, workshop-style introduction to techniques, perspectives and theories unique to performing in television commercials.
Practical experience in the entertainment industry.
Individual research and readings. Not available for graduate credit.
Budgets, contracts, box-office procedures, public relations; personnel and executive policies of the school, community, and professional theatre.
A survey of the influence of historical and cultural events on the evaluation of theatrical styles. Classical to Jacobean.
Guidance and direction in the production of new and experimental plays for a public audience. By audition.
Intensive participation in a production sponsored by the school and supervised by the faculty, to increase and develop artistic growth.
Studies in selected areas of theatre art. Intensive practice in role and script interpretation and its psychological relationship to the audience.
Investigates art and craft of dramatic writing initiated/completed in other MFA in Dramatic Writing courses or that was submitted as a sample for program entry.

Plays for the stage shall be written using public-domain poetry and prose as inspiration and source material, complemented with exploring poetry, prose, and varied dramas as context for the student writer. Students should be well-versed in literature, and have written in one or more genres.
The development and building of auditioning skills for film, television and new media venues.
Advanced exercises in movement for the use of the body in relation to the stage.
Advanced exercises in movement for the use of the body in relation to the stage. Includes Viewpoints and Clown.
Advanced training in acting skills; emphasis upon individual needs.
Advanced training in acting skills; emphasis upon individual needs and solo performance.

course_name: Writing the Pacific Rim: Global and Western Dramatic Writing
description: Writing dramatically, utilizing the Pacific Rim and the Western United States as cultural sites of knowledge and as inspirations.
Close textual reading of dramatic texts as a fundamental tool for rehearsal and performance.
Individual work in improving the actor's vocal range.
Individual work in improving the actor's vocal range.
Individual work in improving the actor's vocal range.
Fundamentals of speech, diction, dialects and accents, including work in the International Phonetic Alphabet.
An introduction to the various facets of singing in theatrical performance
To provide the basic foundations for the conceptualization and execution of works for the stage.
Investigates gestalt of the student dramatic writer's professional development from the empty page and writing fundamentals to the first-draft script, business affairs, and dramaturgical advancement.

course_name: Dramatic Writing Across Media for Playwrights
description: Intensive overview of career paths for playwrights in a wide array of media as they exist now, and as new opportunities arise.

course_name: Dramatic Writing Across Media for Playwrights
description: Intensive overview of career paths for playwrights in a wide array of media as they exist now, and as new opportunities arise.
Advanced creative projects
Structured to address the dynamics of acting in relation to film/television. Refining the students understanding of the similarities/differences between acting on stage/film.
Research leading to the Master's Degree. Maximum units which may be applied to the degree to be determined by the department. Graded CR/NC.
Designed to guide the MFADW student toward refinement of thesis including vision, development, and execution.
Substantive participation in productions sponsored by the school and supervised by the faculty.
